WRITING.TITLE: Questions about Intimidation (RAW)
WRITING.TEXT: I'd like to discover why Intimidation is ever picked over Persuasion (a skill that doesn't leave NPCs with negative feelings toward the character). The Charisma (Intimidation) skill is a social interaction skill that players often try to use in combat to Frighten creatures. As far as I can tell this is based on DM fiat rather than any RAW rule that permit that use of Intimidation. The only rules I see related to it are based on getting creatures to change behaviours out of combat. The questions: 1. What can you do, RAW, with Intimidation, in a combat situation (if anything)? 2. What racial features work with Intimidation (e.g. Kalashtar in Eberron can get Advantage on Intimidate checks)? 3. What class features work with Intimidation? 4. What feats make use of Intimidation (e.g. Dragon Fear from Xanathar's)? 5. I know that Friendship and Enhance Ability can give Advantage on Charisma checks (including Intimidation) but do any spells interact with Intimidation at all?

WRITING.TITLE: GUI access to Ubuntu
WRITING.TEXT: I run Ubuntu on an Intel NUC to act as a web server. I'm about to get rid of my desktop monitor, which I currently use to access the Ubuntu GUI environment (it's the default for 18.04). I want to avoid SSH access for a number of reasons - I only locally access my server at the moment. I have a laptop and an iPad Pro. What are the most elegant ways to connect to my Ubuntu device, that are robust to power outages (I'm a bit worried about relying on RDP in case there's a problem I need to fix). My question could easily be phrased as "how can I use a laptop or an iPad Pro as an external monitor for Ubuntu" but I figure someone here may have dealt with a similar issue and have a good resolution. My backup position is buying a small external portable monitor, but I'd like to have less stuff than more stuff.

The article is much more thoughtful than the headline, unsurprisingly. Brexit *has* revealed an utter failure of British politicians to think ahead (Cameron), to get to grips with a problem (May), to be honest (Hammond), and it has culminated in Johnson. Throughout it all it has exposed the gulf in social differences and participation between those who benefit from the status quo and those who do not. And it could only have happened this way during a period when the Opposition is an utter shambles. I don't think Britain is weak and helpless, certainly not as weak as many other Remainers say, but we do very much need to work out what we want to do with our country and get a (sizeable) majority to agree on it. Maybe the world's business centre is what we want. Maybe we do need to lower immigration and revisit the benefits and flaws of multiculturalism. Maybe we need to accept that greydawn is coming and increase immigration but put more effort into assimilation. I don't know the answer, but it's clear that we as a country need to work through schisms far larger than Brexit.

Agree with a lot of other posts, particularly that it's about power gaming. My experience of it is that it is often shaped by people watching TV or reading books, and wanting to play *the* hero instead of *a hero*. D amp;D is a game where every player should be on an level playing field. Often these "my theme is X" aren't even intentionally power gaming, they are trying to find a way to replicate the power of the character they imagine (sometimes but not always lifted off something else) in a way that fulfils their narrative expectations. When they see the barbarian with full Eldritch Knight casting rules whilst raging on plate, they don't think "that's ridiculous", they think "that's so awesome, it's like X from my favourite show ... my character will be so cool!" What they don't realise is that other players who take normal characters can easily come to resent the overpowered homebrew, and have no interest in picking a janky class from D amp;Dwiki.

That's not in any way a relevant comparison. The EU has grand strategic goals (in as much as that's possible for an organisation with so many stakeholder groups) that require it to not give ground to the UK. Key amongst these are deterring other organisations from leaving the EU, showing solidarity with constituent EU nations, and maintaining the costs and benefits of the Single Market and Customs Union. It's also not suggesting it will close borders to the UK - no-one anywhere has said that *they* will build any kind of physical block for trade. Meanwhile, the issue with Turkey is about whether the EU will permit Turkey to ethnically cleanse non-EU people without a struggle, or risk blocking the borders, blocking trade, and having Turkey funnel millions of refugees into the EU at a time when that's politically difficult. The situations are only analogous in the sense that they involve the EU and a third party.
So the EU don't have a position on this yet?

"The EU likely has no interest in playing along" so your claim is essentially that the lives of Kurds are of equal value to the EU as maintaining its own integrity. Roger that, let's see how this plays out.

You don't even need all of the 4-6 encounters of 8 to be fights: they can be skill tests where the players get to use resources for a benefit of some kind. You also don't need the PCs to feel at risk of death every fight. Healing Spirit helps the pace of the game, and ultimately lets players keep on doing active hero stuff rather than spend hours messing around with Goodberry. There's also a strong argument that a highly efficient out-of-combat heal is more of a spell slot tax on a class than it is a benefit: the caster is obliged to do use level 2 spell slots on it.

Mainly the foreign policy section which is less sovereignty than we have now. If you're a Brexiteer wanting to know why the deal is bad, you can read about it on the Eurosceptic Bruges Group website instead of the Grauniad. Quote follows. https://www.brugesgroup.com/blog/the-revised-withdrawal-agreement-and-political-declaration-a-briefing-note 5. and 6. Prevents independent military action The Treaty permanently restricts the UK's sovereignty by preventing the UK from taking "any action likely to conflict with or impede" EU foreign policy (Article 129(6)). It is instructive that this contrasts with almost all the other sub-sections of Article 129 - each of which include language limiting them to the duration of the transition period. It is also very revealing in the Political Declaration that critical parts of the section on foreign policy and security are not reciprocal. For example, para 99 confirms that the future relationship will not "prejudice the decision-making autonomy of the EU" but no such language is afforded to the UK - we are merely permitted to "maintain the right to determine how [to respond] to any invitation to participate in operations or missions". Additionally, in the Political Declaration the parties "agree to consider" security collaboration in the European Defence Agency, the European Defence Fund and PESCO "to the extent possible under [EU law]" (para 102(c)) which is a prescriptive obligation and not merely a permissive option. Despite making payments to the European Defence Agency during the transition period, British troops in EU battlegroups will not be led by British staff officers (Articles 129(7) and 156-157).

This book is a level of power creep unseen even by Hexblade Warlocks, it will need to be excluded from the +1 rule. Some parts of it seem reasonable. Some parts, such as letting Bards and Sorcerers pick new spells on a Long Rest, beggar belief. That substantially negates the value of being a Wizard, simply because you won't often need X utility spell, so the once-per-day limit is not important. In particular it seems to me that it removes the downside of the Divine Sorcerer, which is limited spell slots. I'm also distinctly disappointed that Champion got no love, and Battle Master - the most played type - got more love.
Not for Wizards! They just get to know Divine Soul Sorcerers are now the best spellcasters. The new Mystic Theurge, if you will.
Sorcerers, in particular Divine Soul Sorcerers, can now change spells on a long rest. This is one hell of a buff they've just got.
The limit on Sorcerer power was that they lacked flexibility. There's now very little reason to be a Wizard over a Divine Soul Sorcerer.
Instead of +1 AC and a weapon feat? Manoeuvres aren't as good as either of those things.
They can get Ritual Casting with a feat, and Sorcery Points beat Arcane Recovery.
Wizards can regain 10 levels of spell at level 20. Sorcerers can regain two 5th level spells at level 14, or that plus six points of metamagic at level 20.

Divine Soul now can pick spells every long rest, which negates the most stringent limit they have. As for Bladesinger ... I've never seen one look good. I play in campaigns that usually have the full 6-8 encounters per day. Sure, Bladesingers are hard to hit, sometimes, but that's not really a game changer.

Obviously. However, Sorcerers have some great features, and don't forget they can get spells back on an action, not on a short rest. At 20, they also get four sorcery points back per short rest: so really they aren't losing that much. Let's look at Divine Soul. As well as metamagic and sorcery points and a spell list to kill for, they get +2d4 on a failed save or attack roll once/short rest, permaflight, and bonus action to return half their lost hit points once/long rest. I'll ignore Empowered Healing because it's weak, and contests sorcery point usage. That's not "no class features"Plus, and this is the kicker, they base off Charisma which means they can win at the social pillar as well as the combat pillar, and also multi class effectively. Those things are almost as good as Wizard features (and better than the weak Wizard archetypes), plus metamagic is amazing for action economy.

Undoubtedly, but Concentration is the limit on caster power that was badly needed to balance this edition. That said, in its current form it is weak. If I could add one, I'd rather like there to be two Concentration slots, one for self-only buffs and one for any buff that can't affect the caster (or use them both for multiple target spells that include the caster). Then casters couldn't be doubly selfish, but also we would see more use of spells that simply can not justify their Concentration slot in the current game. Alas ...

If any multi class is grim with new Ranger 1, it's Monk. Wisdom modifier, Concentration-free Hunter's Mark and Flurry of Blows. That's a regular 1d6 extra damage per attack with three regular attacks from level 5. Four attacks at the cost of a Ki. Plus you can add in hilarious things like the use of the Whip as a martial arts weapon that scales up in damage and has Finesse and Reach. I'd guess overall you'd want Fighter 1 for Duelling and Ranger 1 for Hunter's Mark. At level 17 Monk you may as well swap the Longsword out for a Whip to get Reach. Alternatively do Cleric or Druid 1 for cantrips and spells, and wield your Longsword in two hands for d10 damage (Versatile). One point of damage less than Fighter 1's Duelling style, but I would probably go Forge Cleric 1 because you can make your Longsword a +1 Longsword (makes up for loss of Duelling entirely, in fact gets you a +1 overall) and cast your choice of Bless, Protection from Evil and Good, or Shield of Faith (since Hunter's Mark doesn't take your Concentration). Kensai gives you a sweet +2 AC boost and you can't dip two levels into Diviner for Portent Quivering Palm because you're Ranger, so may as well do Kensai. Overall this gets you a great set of stats and even with early dips (probably going Monk 1-5, Ranger 1, Cleric 1, Monk X) you'll get all your defining bits and bobs early. It's just as MAD as a normal monk with one less ASI (that ASI hurts, but oh well) since every class needs either DEX or WIS.

Going to have to disagree with the basic contention here: power creep is throughout this document, and it doesn't fix some of the biggest issues. It also makes the huge mistake Wizards of the Coast made with Hexblades: the changes are far too front loaded (including Ranger) which means they're making more attractive dips instead of more attractive classes. This is a better Ranger, but Favoured Foe needs to scale with Ranger level somehow. As, probably, does Beast Master.
Yes, that's the problem.

Your thesis: the UA is not merely power creep, and it offers value by making classes more attractive. My rebuttal: the UA is merely power creep, because it just makes class dips attractive. It doesn't make it more attractive to stay in the traditional "dip" classes, like Champion, but makes Ranger attractive as a dip rather than an ongoing choice. So yes: I believe it's just power creep.

The only reason I didn't say "definitely" is because I haven't worked out yet what the value of a Bonus Action is in the new UA world. It seems like having it on a Beast Master pet is good, but plenty of the top tier DPS builds already rely on their Bonus Action - so this just may make Beast Master an attractive dip. It's also not clear whether that Bonus Action Maul attack counts as the Companion taking the Attack action (so it gets two attacks at level 11) or not. Unfortunately they've twisted themselves into such hilarious knots with their definitions of "attack", "Attack", etc that we will need to wait for clarity on whether this Bonus Action attack is like a Booming Blade attack (you make a lower class attack that isn't an Attack action) or whether it's an Attack action.

Your post text is that your thesis is that we shouldn't dismiss the UA *just* because it's power creep. But alright: let's take your title thesis, as opposed to your post thesis. Is there anything inherently wrong with power creep? Yes. Yes there is. In your terms, this UA creates *party imbalance*. It does so by making multi-class more attractive. One of the joys of 5E when released (pre-Hexblade) was that there wasn't much of a power differential between single class builds and multi-class builds. Sorcadins and Diviner/x combos to force failed saves were there, but they didn't overshadow the plain old Battle Master. There were some weak archetypes, and archetypes that are best used for dips (Champions, Warlocks), but only original Ranger was truly gimped. XGTE increased Ranger spell support so they became less bad at high level, but it added Hexblade, increasing the power of Charisma based multi-class. And that's where party imbalance becomes a problem. A perfect system allows flavourful character customisation with straightforward characters not being far behind highly customised characters. The single class character should not be left in the shade by the multi-class dip monster. But that's exactly what this UA encourages. Avoiding this is usually achieved by spreading class benefits out across the levels, ensuring class benefits synergise with each other, and giving the class a solid capstone. Cleric is a perfect example of a good class: it has spells that scale well, and the capstone is guaranteed Divine Intervention. It's worth taking Cleric to 20. Rogue is another great class: decent combat damage output, good survivability, good utility. Druid is a much ropier class, and that's because of its capstone. Unlimited Wild Shape is very powerful for Moon Druids, but meaningless for any Druid archetype that doesn't get value from Wild Shape uses. Wizard is a good class, but the capstone is so bad that there's no value in taking the last two levels instead of a two level dip in some other class (a full spellcaster one, preferably, to keep slots). Warlock with Eldritch Blast invocations, Champion with increased crit range, etc just invite dips. This UA does not spread internally synergistic abilities across the levels: it front loads externally synergistic abilities. In the case of Ranger, it front loads them to a similar extent that Warlock does. Playing a standard published campaign? A Wood Elf Kensai 5, UA Ranger 1, Forge Cleric 1 will hit superpower at level 7 and cruise through for the last 3 to 5 levels of the campaign. It will certainly create massive party imbalance compared to a single classed Fighter, or Monk, that doesn't take those dips. This puts us back in the situation we had in 4E and 3E, where system knowledge and character planning are going to have a huge impact on in-game party balance. That's not one of the design goals of 5E - in fact I'm fairly sure it's something they want to avoid. This means the UA is power creep, and power creep *is* bad. If everyone is more powerful, you've just made bigger numbers: congratulations, you've recreated the 4E treadmill and feat taxes. If only people with great system knowledge are more powerful, you've just ruined party balance: congratulations, you've recreated the 3E splatbookocalypse. I do think this kind of activity (replacements for core class features) does need to happen. For sure there are classes that really lack things (Champions and stuff to do outside combat; Ranger Natural Explorer and Favoured Enemy features are too specific; etc). But this UA is going to reinforce existing problems, not fix them.

It absolutely does: arguably more than combat, because most Sorcerers will have a core set of combat spells anyhow. This will just mean they can be more useful outside of combat without making meaningful choices.

It's not valuable for damage. There's a relatively narrow window for attack rolls that make Sharpshooter's damage boost worth the -5 to hit, and the more base damage you do with an attack, the narrower that window becomes. This change makes the feat damage effect (virtually) always worse than not using the feat (exceptions being if you will still hit on a 2+ after the penalty, or if you only hit on a critical). At any other time you won't want to use the damage portion. You may still want it for hitting at long range and ignoring cover.

The fact that it's a Battle Master with Precise Shot makes this even worse. Firstly, remember that except against something with a very high or very low AC, the difference between hitting and missing is still going to be ~25% over him being a Battle Master and *not* using Sharpshooter (that just shifts the window by an amount dependent on level). Secondly remember, if you have to use Precision Attack to hit, then you're not able to do extra damage with the superiority dice. In this case, you're adding an average based of 4.5 to hit (less than the Sharpshooter penalty of -5) to gain an average of 4.5 damage with a Longbow. So in damage terms this feat is worthless until at least level 10, when your Superiority die adds an average of 5.5 to hit in exchange for 4.5 damage ... but wait! You could instead use the dice to add 5.5 damage with an extra effect using a different manoeuvre. OP has to be using a ranged weapon that does a higher damage dice than his superiority dice for it to ever be worth using this feat.

Starting point: Porter's Value Chain, https://www.omg.org/spec/BMM/About-BMM/ , or whatever equivalent you already have. Identify the processes your senior management agree (or have signed off) as your most important processes (these will usually be the added value processes). Then: double check your processes with a sensible structure. The APQC has a great set of standard processes and a few industry versions (https://www.apqc.org/ ). These won't have the things that are very specific to your business, that's where the starting point comes in. Then work through as time and resource allows. One thing you need to think about upfront is *how are you going to model these* and capture information. You don't want to have to re-do this work, so you want to get the information into an accessible format and (ideally) one that supports measurements and quality control, so later on you can do business optimisation.

That's not a progressive tax. There's no way to opt out of it, or insulate those on benefits from it. Progressive taxes are ones where we can ensure the wealthiest pay more, and the poorest pay less - which we can't achieve with this. There may be a case for nationalising infrastructure where there is no real competition (almost all transport comes under this banner, as does OpenReach although some cable companies deliver their own fibre). But don't pretend it's free, and don't pretend that this is a progressive way of paying for it.

I responded to your response to me. My point is that this broadband tax is not a progressive income tax, because the companies funding it will recoup their losses by increasing advertising costs, and the companies paying for advertising will increase the cost of goods or services. Because goods and services are consumed by everyone, this is going to be regressive for the same reason that VAT is regressive.

What?! "Could not say if it had an effect" and "not quantifiable" is ... meaningless, given you can never know if you've seen all the relevant information. That just tells us that the investigators took the time to look for an effect (presumably prioritising the most likely evidence first) and found nothing. I sincerely hope this is because they couldn't make a definitive statement about cause and effect, and not just that they realised social media reinforces bias rather than changing it. Bots on Twitter sharing propaganda is evidence of activity, but not evidence of impact. If this is it, Grieve is going to look like an idiot and so are No. 10.

There's no evidence (that I've seen at all) that social media can change peoples' pre-existing biases. I've seen some evidence that it can reinforce them, but not change them. Logically it will be harder to change someone's politics than their choice of toothpaste. The only way to test this that I can think of would be to identify some areas of the UK with stable opinions about some issue, do a local sustained blitz on social media about that issue, and then measure the opinions again across the same group of people. Whilst all the while ensuring it's a blind study where the participants don't know what they are being studied for. There are similar efforts in brand loyalty but our choice of vote and politics are likely stable (they are parts of our identity). Whereas unless you're from Yorkshire and morally obliged to claim that literally everything from Yorkshire is better than anything created outside Yorkshire, your choice of specific consumer product won't key into your identity (although wealth demonstrations are part of our identity, I'd guess that millionaires could probably be swayed from a Rolls Royce to a Bentley or Aston Martin without being threatened).

I ran out of boxes to let Wizards know all the ways in which Spell Versatility was the wrong fix for players trying to dodge meaningful choices. With a gentle reminder that the proposed Ranger was a front-loaded dumpster fire, like Hexblade.

Why do they need saving? It's already within a DM's power to say "of course you can trade out that spell that's never used". Or, indeed, "that spell sucks, but it's key to your background. You can have it without it counting against your spells known - pick another." Creating a set of rules that are wholly unnecessary doesn't benefit anyone. If your DM accepts optional variants, they would have accepted the change anyhow. What really matters is whether these are default accepted in Adventurers' League ... and they shouldn't be. They skew the game very heavily.

As my post made clear, the complaint is that they are unnecessary - unless they're planned for inclusion in Adventurers' League. AL is as close as the game gets to the concept of approximate balance between classes. If it's not going into AL, then it's up to any DM and the rules aren't needed at all. Just add a note somewhere reminding DMs that they can let characters change class feature choices (most DMs are probably happy to do this). If it is going into AL, then it's a terrible instance of game design because it won't address fundamental issues with the classes, and it further puts Charisma-based spellcasters ahead of the power curve. Ultimately it comes down to whether or not you think class balance is an important thing. If you don't think it matters, then of course Spell Versatility is great. It doesn't matter if your game becomes 95% Bards and Sorcerers with two level Warlock dips, because that's not what you care about. If you do think class balance is important, then this gives Bards and Sorcerers *more* access to spells than Wizards (no need to scribe scrolls), class features that are fantastic (as described above, action economy efficiency with metamagics, or the many Bard features). Wizards having flexibility over spells to prepare *was* their main class feature, and this gives that to all other classes.

I disagree. Classes with proficiency in INT saves only use those against three monsters in the base Monster Manual. There's no inherent problem in adding INT based saves to the game: in balance terms, it needs it. However they definitely need to be in line with other spells, e.g. no SuperTasha's. Psionicist Blast is about right: smaller area of effect than Cone of Cold, less damage even if pumped up to be an equal spell level, but easier to land.

5E is well balanced as long as you stick to its assumptions. Unfortunately, one of these assumptions is 6-8 resource draining encounters per long rest - and that becomes hard, tiring work as campaigns climb above level 5 (when casters get Plant Growth), again at 9 (Wall of Force) and all levels above 13 (shenanigans levels). Fighters do the best single target damage but only come into their own in long fights, where other classes can't blow all their resources with impunity. There's a tendency to only have a few, important fights at high levels - just so games aren't hour upon hour of combat - and that rewards Long Rest resource classes and hurts the others (particularly Champion). The way to balance the current game is to buff up the Social and Exploration pillars for no rest and Short Rest classes. It's not to give Charisma-based casters even more buffs and let them dominate the last pillar that they didn't already totally dominate (Exploration).

The build is primarily because Wizard has (or had) more options for Lightning damage than Tempest Cleric. Divine Intervention has a 100% chance at level 20, and a 19% chance at level 19. That's a big difference in terms of action economy - essentially it makes it usable in combat. Logically it seems odd, but nothing stops someone just repeatedly blowing actions out of combat to get Divine Intervention: presumably Clerics that hit level 10 often win the lottery, they just need to pray for an average of seven actions to get Divine Intervention.
Indeed: the god tier build, with 9th level spells and colossal damage and great survivability.

It's quite possible to address the issues in a more refined way. Let's be charitable, and assume the complaints about Sorcerer (objectively the best combat caster class) are not because people want to dodge meaningful choices, but because they can't have a themed spell list and still pick the best combat spells. This can be resolved by adding a small selection of appropriate utility spells and combat spells that aren't normally picked, to each Sorcerer Archetype. This completely addresses the inability to flavour Sorcerers complaint, without deeply changing class relationships. Of course, a player may pick a bad spell (Witch Bolt) ... but they can always discuss that with their DM. If the DM will permit the change, they'll do that regardless of optional rules. That's only a marginal increase in power, but a big increase in ability to customise and flavour Sorcerer. There are no losers, only winners.

18 Cleric is indeed also awesome. I think the key point about Divine Intervention is that it's basically an extra level 7 to 9 spell slot. Very DM dependent, but still great! And vastly better than two extra level 3 spell slots for Wizard.
Those DMs aren't going to adopt these optional rules, I expect. There are a lot of fake choices for Sorcerers.

I don't discount enhancements, I just want them to focus on the bigger picture rather than letting people avoid meaningful choices and seriously increasing the flexibility of two classes whose power is only really limited by their lack of flexibility.

There is no solution. Ultimately people are choosing to look at an ambiguous situation and interpreting it in different ways. The facts are confusing enough to mean there's no obvious "reality". Can surgery and the desire to be something different change our true nature (or reveal a true nature we had all along, even if it was limited to a part of the brain and every other part of our body expressed it differently)? Do we even have a true nature to change? Probably not. For some people, the idea that what people feel can take precedence over external physical reality is simply *baffling*. For others, the imperfect sex-based categorisation of people is less important than allowing people to believe what makes them less unhappy. I'd say this is a fundamental difference in understanding the world and trans issues will probably take longer to be accepted than homosexual relationships: it doesn't require changing a moral attitude, it requires changing the way you interpret reality. Until we get robots to replace every unwanted human interaction, we will continue to experience these clashes. In the meantime, hospital trusts are going to attempt to please everyone (in this case, acceding to the patient's request, telling trans patients they thought it was unacceptable, then apologising to everyone).

Booming Blade is made through a weapon attack, not a melee spell attack. This means your concept is AL viable with PHB + SCAG. Go High Elf, take level 1 in Fighter (hit points and better saves) and the Booming Blade cantrip. Go Rogue 4 (Swashbuckler plus Dexterity ASI) then Fighter 3 Champion. Then just take more Rogue levels. You get the crit range of 19-20, the combat power, and everything. All you miss out on is Elven Accuracy and that's impossible to get with Booming Blade in AL.

For sake of clarity: I absolutely think trans people should get treatment, help and support for whatever intervention they need. Physical reality *is* reality. Mental reality is our perception, which goes through whatever filters are in place and which may, or may not, be an accurate representation of reality. I did not say that you should change to make me more comfortable: I asked what the logical basis was for saying that part of a brain's wiring outweighed potentially every other part of a body. You essentially asked if I would object to having my personality changed, since I was suggesting that for others. My response is that I don't have an issue with my sexuality that requires changing so the analogy doesn't work. If I had a set of perceptions that was causing me distress, though, and you could change my personality so they didn't cause me distress - then absolutely I would go for that. Finding the world isn't as we want it is understood by many philosophies to be the root of suffering. Zen, Stoicism, etc all focus on accepting what is and changing our wants to match reality. Those are good rules to live by and to reduce suffering. If they came in pill form, I'd take it.

WRITING.TITLE: AMD Chromebook and Android apps
WRITING.TEXT: I'm new to ChromeOS. Grabbed myself a Lenovo S345 in the sales. It has an A4 chip. I've got it to see if I can move my parents across from their aging Windows laptops to something cheap and cheerful. One does nothing other than emails and web browsing. Chromebook can easily do this if I can just get over the technical hurdle of it being slightly different to the existing Windows PC. The other does karaoke via SingSnap. I tried logging in to that benighted site via my Chromebook and although I could listen to recordings, it demanded installation of the Android app to make new recordings. I duly went to the Play Store app and didn't see Singsnap. I then tried browsing the Play Store via web browser, and it said that the Chromebook was incompatible with Singsnap. I've also found that Firefox Focus crashes on start up, and Firefox Preview has weird scrolling problems using the trackpad. Is the AMD chip on this Chromebook responsible for these oddities? It was cheap and did well in benchmarks but that's a lot of failure in a couple days of mild use cases (Firefox and Singsnap). Any ideas on what I could do to get them to work? It does seem I can do some kind of Linux compatibility.

I stood up an instance of Semantic MediaWiki. Requires slight technical knowledge but is very flexible and powerful. For example, I can do adventure write ups, note which characters were on the adventure, and assign experience. The more players you have, the better it is to put in work up front to automate managing the campaign.

Seconding the "common answers" part. In my case, I got a book on interviews ("Why you?" But all those books are probably the same), made a spreadsheet of the fifteen most common questions and the fifteen most common competency questions, and a Word document of long form responses to each (as a memory jog). Each time I get an interview I assess the bullets from the job description, expand the master question list if necessary (usually around technical, rather than generic, skills) and just keep updating that. I add to it after an interview if I get blindsided. It's a load of work up front, but you soon start to see similarities in the questions and being able to match the job spec to existing answers saves a load of time. You can then focus on researching the company, writing the presentation or whatever they ask you to do, and the "why my experience is useful to you" pitch.
This is a thing of beauty.

Use cases (in my experience) will come before requirements, in a waterfall or iterative environment. I don't do detailed use cases, but I do Use Case Diagrams and then flesh them out with requirements, acceptance criteria etc. Each of the Use Cases in that linked site could spawn a number of requirements, e.g. ironing requires an iron capable of working with synthetic or wool clothes.

I am. I've never seen the value of use cases as such - if I need detail about an interaction, I do a process map in BPMN. If I don't need detail, I use the use case diagram. Then again I work more at the Business level rather than the Data/Application level. Either way, if you're asked to produce detailed written use cases, they will be used to frame and categorise your requirements so you get traceability back through the use case. They will help ensure you don't miss anything. If you want a reference, I recommend looking at Domain Driven Design or "Mastering the Requirement Process" (or both).
"Mastering the Requirements Process" is a book by Robertson and Robertson. Domain Driven Design - there's an intro book here. https://www.infoq.com/minibooks/emag-domain-driven-design/
This looks amazing but I am too lazy. I would pay for this.
Expense - easier to let the opposition pay for it, when there's no election.

The government won't do anything, but if some manager orders workers to come in and there's a suspected transmission in the office, the negative publicity will almost certainly result in them being fired.

"Company spreads pandemic" is the kind of negative publicity that will see share prices tank and whole boards cleared. Maybe your friend's company is privately held and won't be affected, but in the round, we will likely see a lot of managers fired for not taking it seriously. Humans have a fear of disease on a primal level (e.g. https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/long-history-disease-and-fear-other-180953310/ ).

Coronavirus is forever, not just for Christmas. The messages from the medical professionals made sense to me - it is going to go through the population, if not now then later. The countries that locked down and prevented the spread are still going to get it later as it circulates the globe and comes back in a few month's time. The gamble is really whether safe and effective cures (hah) or vaccines will come out soon (in which case a lockdown would probably have been better, because it would minimise our casualties before treatment and prevention comes online) ... or whether they come out months down the line, in which case lockdown would be unsustainable and we would be just making sure we had multiple waves of this. I do think the government could be doing more for zero hours contractors etcetera to support self-isolation, but the medical advice seems logical and it seems like that is what they are following.
I think you're right, which is why I think the government is taking a well-reasoned approach.

WRITING.TITLE: Unity and Ultimate
WRITING.TEXT: During beta players could not connect to my Ultimate server. Now Unity is live, are they able to? They don't have licences, I have the Ultimate licence.
It's usable, therefore it's live. At least by every definition I've seen! Thanks for the tip on lobbies, I'll make sure people can access it before putting work in.
Will do, thanks for the tip.
No. It may have a niche use elsewhere, but live software is software accessible to end users because it's in the live environment. I've not seen it used as a synonym for "officially released".
I didn't say it was ready for prime time, I just said it was live and wanted to check that users without FGU licences could connect to my Ultimate server.
Great! What I need to do most is find a video explaining all the nifty tricks. I've forgotten most of how to run FG Classic and get all the use out of it - and FGU has way more power.

The hit point formula for Aberrant Spirit seems odd. As written, cast at eighth level it's Aberrant Con mod (2, doesn't scale); plus caster ability modifier (5, probably); and if you cast at eighth level for maximum spirit attacks, another (80). That's 87 hit points - very low for the level, and no scaling on the Con or cast stat modifier. I wonder if they meant (Con mod + casting mod + 10) * spell level.
They probably cut and paste the formula. And you could do that, but using a level 5 spell slot to summon a 56 hit point creature seems ... incorrect.
Acid Stream seems far too powerful for a level one spell.

On further consideration, it's probably fine. At the moment it works out for the undead spell as (with AL stats): 3rd level. 2 + 3 + 30, or 35 hit points. 4th level. 2 + 4 + 40, or 46 hit points. 6th level. 2 + 4 + 60, or 66 hit points. 8th level. 2 + 5 + 80, or 87 hit points. In each case, the hit points is two or three attacks from the monsters you'll be fighting. E.g. to cast a third level spell you'll be at fifth level. An Easy encounter would be against a CR5 monster, such as a Bulette. The Bulette average damage is 28. A Barbed Devil with its multi-attack does 22 if each hits, as does a Cambion. By the time you can cast eighth level spells at level 15, an Easy encounter is a single CR 13 mob. A Nalfeshnee does 62 damage with its multi attack. A Storm Giant does 60. Whilst it's dubious that you want an eighth level spell slot to disappear in 1.5 multi-attacks from an enemy, if it could absorb two or three full rounds of attacks from an Easy solo it would probably be bringing too much to the table. Hit points on the lowish side also makes archetypes that give summons temporary hit points more attractive.

How is allowing people from the city to disperse *more* risky than asking people from the city to stay clustered? It vastly reduces the amount of available space. What on Earth leads to you conclude that there's more risk of the virus spreading in the countryside where separation distances can be far greater than in the city?
Just use the service station gloves that most provide for filling up.

Let's start from the basics. Have you ever been outside a city? If people in a city observe social distancing, then why do you think those same people if they drive to the countryside will congregate simultaneously in public toilets? What do you think country dwellers do that means that a person from the city is going to be a highly effective spreader when they are outside? What particular region of the U.K. do you think is currently corona-free for this kind of transmission to matter? As a person who lives rurally, I am sure that city people going for a walk along the lanes or on the public footpath near me is going to be a microscopic increase in my risk compared to me just going to buy food once or twice a week since I'm not hoarding. In comparison, I am sure that those same city people if confined to their own densely-populated areas are more likely to spread the virus and overwhelm the hospital that serves the local area and which I share with those city people. Instead of the countryside wind widely dispersing these miasmic clouds of death that you seem to have imagined based on a report of viability time in lab conditions, those people staying in the city will be coughing onto the same surfaces over and over. The problem isn't even all cities, from the news it's basically people in London - although since London is a fixation for our media, it might be as bad in other places. Maybe they should lock down London and leave the rest of us to it.
Data source? Even if it does happen right now, I wouldn't expect it to last (and I'm not pro-schism).
I'd argue that Trump and Republicans are actively suppressing information - although it's not a federal policy.
As a lefty, I just want you to know that we have publicly disowned the person you replied to.

If you read the science, it discusses aerosolizing the strain and testing viability in a lab. Likewise, the surface tests are in lab conditions. Outside in the real world is not the same as lab conditions. And look at it this way: where are you going to encounter more metal and plastic touched by strangers - the city, or the country? Let's say a person drives out to the countryside. They park up, they get out, they go for a walk. They don't need to touch anything except a stile or a gate - and they can wear gloves for that and handle the gloves appropriately later, just as they would in the city. As long as they continue to observe social distancing of 2m (and that's easier where there is more space), and as long as they are following good hygiene protocols - as you think they will in the city - then there is no additional source of risk, outside of accidents on the journey/mechanical breakdown. Whereas there are many health benefits from being out in natural surroundings. Your point about exponential transmission misses the whole point of this - whether the risk of transmission is increased by people travelling to the countryside, over people walking around town. As I already pointed out, unless people are travelling vast distances they'll be in the same hospital catchment area anyhow. If someone transmits in the country, they'll transmit in the city. The impact is the same, the hospitals are the same. For what you say to be meaningful, there would need to be evidence that rural dwellers transmit the virus more easily than city dwellers and/or that transmission in a rural setting was more probable than in an urban one. I raised London specifically because there are reports that a substantial number of people are just ignoring social distancing there - not because it's further along the curve. And there's a difference between allowing people to drive out to the countryside for their daily exercise, to dispersing the population of two metropoli and Lombardy for an undefined time to an undefined place. Even your straw man is illogical.

gt; It's not, but then what are you basing your assessment of how long it will take then? I was responding to someone saying it would be gone in minutes... based on nothing. Are you telling me to look at the science so you can ignore the science and base your opinion on your own speculation?! The science tells us the worst case scenario, so we should base it on that. Let's take a look at the reports, in case you missed some important points in your ... interpretation. "In the context of COVID-19, airborne transmission may be possible in specific circumstances and settings in which procedures that generate aerosols are performed (i.e. endotracheal intubation, bronchoscopy, open suctioning, administration of nebulized treatment, manual ventilation before intubation, turning the patient to the prone position, disconnecting the patient from the ventilator, non-invasive positive-pressure ventilation, tracheostomy, and cardiopulmonary resuscitation). In analysis of 75,465 COVID-19 cases in China, airborne transmission was not reported. ... A recent publication in the New England Journal of Medicine has evaluated virus persistence of the COVID-19 virus.9 In this experimental study, aerosols were generated using a three-jet Collison nebulizer and fed into a Goldberg drum under controlled laboratory conditions. This is a high-powered machine that does not reflect normal human cough conditions. Further, the finding of COVID-19 virus in aerosol particles up to 3 hours does not reflect a clinical setting in which aerosol-generating procedures are performed #8212;that is, this was an experimentally induced aerosol-generating procedure." (Source: https://www.who.int/news-room/commentaries/detail/modes-of-transmission-of-virus-causing-covid-19-implications-for-ipc-precaution-recommendations ). gt; It's about distance of transmission - moving from areas of high concentration to areas of much lower concentration. We're talking about people going for exercise not shopping - if they're just exercising within a few km of their local area, they're not going to be dealing with parking meters, styles, gates, public toilets, getting refreshments from corner shops etc. Why is it about that? Who's going to be checking Pay-and-Displays in the country right now? What corner shops are going to be open up in the hills? Probably very few. And there's no evidence that they are going to be more used than similar parking areas (more likely to be checked in urban areas) and corner shops (more likely to be open in urban areas) because there is more potential custom still in the urban areas. gt; Gloves are not mandated, and can still spread infection. People can still sneeze or cough or sweat into their hands, Yes if people went to the countryside in hazmat suits you'd be fine, but that might not happen. Again, why take unnecessary risks? People are either going to be careful or they are not. There are two failures for you to pick up the virus - the person who had it for not wearing gloves and for coughing on stiles, and your own for touching the stile then wiping your face. The exact same could happen on benches in urban areas, opening a door to a block of flats, and so on. Wouldn't it be much simpler to just tell people they need to wear gloves? gt; It increases the risk of people spreading from the town to the countryside. As I said, by your logic we should spread out all the people in London, Wuhan (a few months ago), Lombardy and NYC into the countryside, but that would be idiotic. That's not what I said. I said we could just lockdown London, which is the opposite of that. And I then explained why. You're just reaching to make an absurd point that is nothing to do with what I said. gt; The controversial point was someone who travelled from Sheffield to Curbar Gap in the Peak District (which does have a car park with a parking meter) which would be served by hospitals in Chesterfield or Matlock, rather than the hospitals in Sheffield, and if it spreads to other people driving to the same area from other cities, then of course you would have transmission from cities to towns. Every hospital is going to have people with it. An isolated incident of people driving a very long distance isn't going to change that. Any hospitals in Chesterfield and Matlock are going to get patients with COVID anyhow. gt; Well it is further along the curve. There's more people in London, that doesn't mean they're ignoring social distancing at a greater rate. People are also unable to travel to work (which is allowed) on the tube at peak times and follow social distancing - it's not about exercise/leisure which is what you're talking about. Popular tourist spots in central London are now empty - you seem to want people to be replacing them with popular tourist spots in the countryside, which is utterly nonsensical. If people stay close to their own homes, they'll be far more spread out than if they all congregate in the countryside's most beautiful tourist spots. That's not happening right now because most people are following guidelines - if we changed the guidelines as you seem to want, it would be happening in mass numbers and more than usual, because that would be the only allowable leisure activity. Popular tourist spots in London are small and, in many cases, indoors or in small areas. Going out to walk along South Downs is a very different matter. gt; It is completely illogical - I'm just following your logic to it's natural conclusion. If you think there's a difference then which of your principles does it break? So long as we spread them out enough to the whole of the Italian countryside, by your logic, there should be no issue. But yes, it is completely illogical... If we did spread everyone out with a 2m gap and kept them there for three weeks and they didn't have to move then yes, we would probably stop the virus. However that's ridiculous and nothing like people going out to get the general health benefits of an isolated walk in natural surroundings (e.g. https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/07/180706102842.htm but there's no shortage of articles about mental health improvements from being outside).

Did dragons actually fight alongside the army? If so, here are some things they might do. 1. Leave space in their formations for a Huge sized monster, in the hope that a Dragon takes that space. If this happens the Dragon could extend its wings over the kobolds (or whoever), potentially providing them with Cover, including against Fireballs. 2. Train special Chosen Ones. These are kobolds who have been trained to run towards the enemy and take the Help action, to assist the Dragon with its attack rolls. They don't expect to live, so the rest of kobold society treats them well (honoured) whilst being glad not to be Chosen themselves. These kobolds are probably stuffed up, much like Berserkers. They may also have a level or two in mobile classes such as Monk, the Mobile feat, or similar. There may even be catapults for launching them towards aerial enemies if their Dragon has to fight another Dragon. That or the kobolds could be in a Howdah on its back. 3. Winged Kobold scouts would screen for the Dragon. They could load up with alchemical smoke and fly between the Dragon and the ground, providing cover from enemy archers and letting the Dragon swoop out of the smoke dramatically. 4. Healing machines. It's an action to interact with an object. However a Dragon has a very large mouth. Potentially many Kobolds could spend their actions hurling healing potions down its throat in nice digestible sacks - Healing Haggis. Or even Goodberries though that might result in Dragon stomach cramps since just one is enough to sustain a creature for a day. 5. Skirmishers. The Dragon is the equivalent of a flamethrower - good at clearing massed groups of enemies. The kobolds would therefore want to encourage the enemies to do that clustering and become vulnerable to the breath weapon. This means they would be shaping the battlefield to the best of their ability. Sneaking up to it in the night, laying traps, trying to funnel enemy forces into kill zones. A narrow gulley where the kobolds could hide caltrops and ball bearings would be ideal. 6. The kobolds would want to screen the Dragon from hostile magic, which would mean ensuring that any nearby casters had a steady stream of dispersed kobolds to worry about. Never more than three, because casters can trivially kill a group of kobolds - but at least one kobold to get in the caster's face. 7. That of course is what the Dragon would want. Kobolds are cowards and there would no doubt be hilarity as they volunteered each other for the suicidal roles and then ran before the battle, leaving the Dragon and a field full of traps.

I like how they cite niche invasion as a reason to ditch the Mystic, but a Wood Elf Psi Knight appears to be able to jump 110' in a single move action at level 3 for no resource cost by Long Jumping with Psionic Talent. When long jumping they can roll their Psi die (1d6 at level 1) and extend the jump by (2*psi dice) + (2*Int modifier). Say they start with Str 12 Int 16, they run 10', jump for (12+(3.5*2)+(3*2)) but that costs them only 1' to go that 25' Repeat two more times and they actually go 75' in Psi-Powered Leap plus their base 35. 110' movement in a single Move action. Edit: amended "level 1" to "level 3".
True fax.
Fair, but even then you're at 54' move as a baby Psi Knight with 30' base speed.
It's a niche invasion for Monk - they're the class with jumping skills.

It's a problem when the UA is so much better at the niche than the original that there's no point being the original, which is what the Psionic Leap feature does. It's vastly better than Step of the Wind.

Look at the maths above. This can be used with repeated long jumps (and even more efficiently, standing long jumps) to cover far more distance. And you can just stop when you want to - you aren't being forced to overshoot. On average this will also be resource free.

Yeah but to be fair he's got to pick odds. This is simple classic game theory, there are only four outcomes. 1. He picks girlfriend, audience picks girlfriend. He wins money and doesn't have his choice hanging over his relationship. 2. He picks girlfriend, audience picks ex. He does not win money and doesn't have his choice hanging over his relationship. 3. He picks ex, audience picks ex. He wins money and has his choice hanging over his relationship. 4. He picks ex, audience picks girlfriend. He does not win money and has his choice hanging over his relationship. There's a double positive and a single positive for picking his girlfriend. There's a single positive or no positive for picking his ex.

I would like to replace my elderly father's PC with a simple-to-use device that is secure and doesn't use Adobe Flash. Unfortunately his two use cases are email (fine) and karaoke (not fine). At the moment he uses Singsnap but I expect I could lure him to do his crooning on Smule or some other social karaoke site. My problem: he has poor sight. The setup would need to link the iPad to a monitor (I believe I can do this with a Lightning-to-USB adapter, or maybe Lightning-to-HDMI). That would leave no port for a microphone, however, and potentially cause charging issues. Which means I need to find a Bluetooth headset that is iOS compatible that has a good quality mic so he can sing into that. My questions: 1. Is there a sensible way to do karaoke apps on a basic iPad with the one port? I can't afford an iPad Pro for him, this setup would be a birthday/Christmas present. 2. Can I actually hook the basic iPad into a monitor without major issues? 3. Are there any Bluetooth headsets that work with the basic iPad and have a good/great mic? 4. Can the basic iPad use some kind of Lightning hub so I could connect a monitor and a Lightning port mic?
How's the trackpad? I use a Bluetooth trackball when travelling, mainly to do a bit of gaming. I understand iOS now accepts mouse input but if the trackpad is good maybe I don't need the trackball.

I loathe homebrew classes, I truly do. This one is the first one I've seen that I not only like, but will introduce to a game I run. Some comments: * the Undead bond seems much weaker than the others. I can't easily articulate why, but certainly compared to the Warrior of the Wild, the Aberration, and the Fey, its combat potential seems very poor. * there's a typo in the description of Blood Demon ("preformed" when you mean "performed"). Another in Conduit of Agony ("it's"). Blood Demon also looks like a juicy multiclass opportunity for anything that does burst damage (e.g. Paladin multiclass with Smite). Smite your Demon and do a lot of area effect damage. However it's governed by enemy Constitution saves, so I think it's balanced - just stronger than most of the other archetypes and with good synergistic opportunity. * Creation has a typo. "Deal and extra" not "an extra" with Blunt Fists. Stomp seems very powerful - 8d8 area effect damage is way higher than most of the other Edicts you have. I suspect this might be too generous, although much lower and it won't be worth taking. Definitely needs play testing given how often Edicts refresh and how this does damage (albeit in a smaller area) comparable to a 3rd level spell slot. Also ... Big Mouth synergy with the Enlarge spell and Soul Infused Giant is amazing. * Ooze. Engulf could stand to be re-written, the wording is odd in places. Also that this is a Medium or smaller target, rather than a target one size category smaller, seems a bit disappointing, because it doesn't synergise with Soul Infused Giant. Given Plant can grapple and restrain creatures of any size, I felt particularly sorry for Ooze. * Split Soul. This one seemed very flavourless compared to the others, in terms of the actual abilities rather than the concept. * Puppet. I really, really like the concept, but the bonuses for it don't seem as flavourful or cool as the other archetypes. Also the top ability is weaker than the Split Soul's top ability since the Soul Binder is encouraged not to act. * Soul Troll. I have so many players that abuse trolls, I couldn't help but laugh. Barbarians in full plate that can cast spells with full casting is the general expectation of homebrew. There are three questions you can ask to determine whether a homebrew is worth reading in depth. 1) does it offer a new take and flavour for something, that you can't already do with an existing class? In this case, yes. Beast Master Ranger is very limited in what it can do and the spin you can put on it. This doesn't invade a niche (the companion is a good pet, but the base class isn't as good as a Ranger at combat for example, and doesn't have the exploration stuff). 2) is the class coherent with itself? Do most of the features make sense with the theme, rather than just arbitrarily giving the class a ribbon ability or random useful thing? The abilities here make sense for the pet class. 3) if the class was available in a game, would a power gamer always pick it? Aka the Hexblade test. This class is not so powerful that it would be played to the exclusion of other things.

The point is that they don't have empathy. They will maintain stable trade, until it's advantageous not to. It's a dire position to be in, and there's not really a magic bullet. You can try to give yourself the feeling of a bit more control. Some ways you could achieve this: 1. Think of job applications as a job. Don't get into the mindset of them being some extra task you fit between your unemployed leisure time, treat them as a Monday to Friday 09:00 to 17:00 job. That doesn't mean just slavishly making applications, you can use that time to research ways to improve your portfolio, write a better CV, write better cover letters. 2. Invest in a book written by a recruitment professional about how to write your CV and covering letter. Ideally from your country, as local cultures vary - many CV re-writing services that are presumably U.S. based just stuff the CV full of self-aggrandising buzzwords that will get your application ignored by U.K. recruiters. Particularly relevant in a field where there is computer-based automatic sifting. 3. Do A-B testing on your CVs and covering letters and portfolio. Particularly if you see some advice that is apparently good but doesn't seem to fit you. Write one CV and covering letter based on that advice, and another based on other advice. Then see if either method produces better results. You're in this for the long game, each time you don't get an invite for interview you do have a data point. 4. Talk to a recruiter in your field. If you can do temp jobs, that's often useful - the recruiter will tell you want employers want and help you with your CV, you do a temporary job for experience and money, and you know what to emphasise in future applications. 5. Don't take rejections personally. 6. My emergency backup plan was to apply for jobs as a recruiter in the field I wanted to work in, then use that to understand what employers wanted and make contacts. Fortunately I didn't have to do it ... but it's something to consider. Good luck.

You should pick a modelling method before picking a tool. And the best way to do that is to think about who you're going to present to, and what they like to see. Some times senior stakeholders are turned off by anything more detailed than a Visio diagram. Sometimes they like full architectural details (it often depends on their level of IT experience). Some methods recommend particular views or viewpoints. Others are integrated relatively well with EA frameworks. Where I work, we model in ArchiMate, which integrates well with TOGAF. We also need to work on modes together. This narrows the field down quite a lot - most of the software is poor. The right software will allow you to do your modelling and map your dependencies, along with either offering an inbuilt way of managing properties and values associated with your modelled content, or at least an easy way to interact with a database that does so. If I was starting from scratch with no particular drivers, I'd look at Archi or Visual Paradigm Online. Both are free for personal use and to get a feel for what is out there. Archi doesn't work well as a shared repository, but it's good for ArchiMate. Visual Paradigm I've used for planning non-work projects, plus it has generically useful Help pages. There are going to be other tools out there with lots of features and low buy in, I just haven't tried them.

Public (particularly political) figures absolutely need to be held to account for their opinions at the next vote. Private citizens, blogging on Suburban_Chad_09's Wordpress site, or some 15 follower Twitter account, should be allowed to talk nonsense (and be castigated for it) but without the hounding elements and attempts by people to get them fired. In any public space there are two responsible parties. One is the speaker, who needs to be aware that they should be willing to defend their ideas robustly. An idea that can't be defended is not much use, after all. But listeners are also responsible. Firstly for making sure they can handle opinions they disagree with, without getting hysterical. Spend the next month writing down stuff you actually make use of, in a list. Then write down what you use it for. You've now got a list of things that you know you are likely to do in any month. Go through it. For example, do you actually use a lamp? If so, what for? How often? Do you use it for handwriting? If so, are you going to be doing much of that in the future, or are you going to be typing on a laptop? Do you use the lamp for reading? If so, are you going to get a Kindle or use a Kindle app so you don't have to carry books? Next make your list of all the things that you need to use the things above. Are there any opportunities to reduce? For example, can you get everything you need onto USB-C? You could go Chromebook or iPad Pro (USB-C powered), and try to ensure anything else essential for your target area works from the sockets you'll have (desk fan if you're going somewhere hot, Kensington laptop lock if it's an area with crime). Look at a travel adapter that can power everything. There are some fancy hubs that also offer wireless charging, if that fits the bill for your electronics - but minimalism is a great way of saving money. One last question I would ask is about internet connection - very much country or campus specific. Do they provide free WiFi? If so, great. Do they provide metered WiFi? Do you use a VPN and, if so, is that within their TOS? Do they snoop your connection more than you want? If it's cheaper to supply your own internet data then plan for that with your phone or a MiFi device.

If you're just showing what exists where, I'd still keep it simple. Components are services (you plug them in and use them) consumed by your PaaS service. The advantage of services is that you're not pre-empting questions like "should I actually be using an Interface instead of a Component" etc. If you really want to model the behaviour of those components (function in ArchiMate is about behaviour) - which I am not sure you do, but it's your example - then you need a structure model. This would look something like: * "Azure Cloud" as Application Component 1 (if you really have to avoid Service ... ) * "Azure SQL DB" as Application Component 2 * "Azure SQL database write" as Application Function 1 * "Azure SQL database storage" as Application Function 2 * Application Function 1 and 2 are nested inside Application Component 2 * Application Component 2 is nested inside Application Component 1 As you can see, by using Functions you're going to have to add a lot to the diagram, because you're effectively telling the Solution Architect *why* each component is being used, and what the important parts are. This can easily result in a very complex diagram. If you just need to list components then Services are better. If you need to show what each component does, Functions are fine. If you need to show how data moves between Components, or how administrators use Interfaces to manage Components, different diagrams again. If that doesn't work, I'd resist the urge to show higher level (application) elements supporting lower level (technology) elements.

No - they are trying to differentiate between biologically born women's rights and trans women's rights. Their argument isn't that trans women shouldn't have their own space, it's that the space shouldn't be shared with biologically born women. That's *not* a denial of rights for trans women, it's a differentiation.

I'm not a TERF - I'm simply pointing out that is their argument, and it's not about denying rights. It's dishonest to claim that it is. You may feel that it's immoral because you are uncomfortable with the differentiation - but they're clearly uncomfortable without it. You determined it to be bigoted, but others believe it's reasonable. There are differences of opinion, and it's clearly not settled. As for me, I don't care if everyone shares a unisex space - I'd be fine with that. But I have the grace to understand that other people may be virulently opposed to that and have good reasons, and I don't pretend my opinion is some kind of received truth. There could be many other examples of this as well. Is it settled that Communism is a busted flush? Clearly not. Is it settled that Capitalism is the end state? I sincerely hope not.

What medical and scientific consensus do you think exists around bathroom sharing rights - or gender dysphoria, for that matter? You make a lot of claims to give the impression that it's settled, and that one side has an obvious moral claim to righteousness - but that's simply dishonest. This can be seen by the sheer volume of arguments about it. It's not a settled issue even in progressive Western societies, let alone the rest of the world.

As stated above, I don't mind who uses what bathroom. I'd prefer unisex bathrooms simply for my personal convenience and because I'd never have to worry about misreading some of the bizarre signs that are in use. I don't have an opinion on women's spaces. I gave an example in the thread about debate, and you demonstrated the point for me by claiming that a number of subjects about just one controversy were "settled" in the "circles that matter". Which is evidently nonsense. I'm not going to tilt at any of your straw men. Not sharing bathrooms isn't the same as not providing bathrooms. For what it's worth, I'm quite happy to agree that gender is a social construct, and sex is a biological one. At that point, it's just a question of whether bathrooms are separate for biological reasons or social ones. As far as I'm concerned the best split is one that lets me have shorter queues - I.e. whatever split supports urinals. There: some agreement. However, my point - as with debating - is that it's dishonest to claim that your side of a controversial argument is correct and settled, as you are, and that the only the other side has to make the argument. Even the medical community as a whole isn't united in agreement with what you're claiming. And I am going to bow out, now. I keep forgetting how intensely divisive and valueless "identity" is as a concept (any identity). My mistake: I should have used a less emotive subject as my example for why no platforming is important.

There are many good arguments for unelected second chambers. 1. Elected representatives are driven by the demands of popularity rather than good governance. This often results in short term thinking ("what will get me more votes" instead of "what will make this country better in the long run"). 2. Experts selected by an appropriate system (e.g. peer nomination) are more likely to have actual expertise than experts trying to get voted in by the general population. Of course, each expert is going to weight their own area of expertise highly when it comes to providing advice. 3. Hereditary peers, more than most, have a vested interest in the long term health of the country: they are literally leaving estates to their descendants. Of course, this also incentivises such peers to provide advice that guarantees things like land rights. 4. Political appointees. In theory, these can be experienced politicians who have decades of dealing with policy under their belts. They are freed up from the requirement of popularity seeking and can focus on providing good advice. Of course, this ends up being a source of political favours and appointments made on the basis of past deeds not future promise. It's difficult. Based on the calibre of our politicians in the social media age, I'm not sure that elections will help. If anything they would be PR elections, which will give fringe parties more of a say. On the other hand, the nakedly political appointments are a disgrace. I'd like to see a system with a few hereditary peers (really), a few bishops, a whole lot of experts elected by their own professions, and some political appointments. The political appointments should last for a fixed term (let's say until the end of the Parliament after they were appointed). This would encourage nominations of Lords who could achieve things. Any party leader who MPs should be able to nominate a representative number of political appointees. Lastly, I'd like about a third of the Lords to be elected in an STV system done on a national list. This would allow some fringe party involvement and help make up for the issues caused by FPTP.

It's not about parentage, as much as it is long term interest in the health of the country through assets that are hard to relocate and the value of which is tied to things like the environment, cleanliness, etc (I.e. land). As an alternative we could just nominate the ninety biggest land owners who pay taxes on their land, but that does rather incentivise the ultra-wealthy to purchase land for political power and then drive up all related costs such as houses.
Tragically so, doesn't mean it needs to be worsened!

Medical literature. I have a medical text on binge eating that says eating isn't addictive in the ways that a drug is. It was written before people really worried about the difference between macro effects, but it's not that old and it's an item I see on book shelves in doctor's offices. There is a prevailing belief that you can't be addicted to things essential to survival, food is essential to survival, and sugar is a food.

The particular book is by an authority on eating disorders and Professor of Psychiatry at one of the world's most prestigious universities. It's from around 2000 which means plenty of general doctors will have trained when it was new. You can try to present sugar addiction as settled science, but you'd be wrong to do so. Even if I personally believe sugar is addictive, that doesn't mean that it's an opinion the general medical establishment shares.

Let's be clear. You are asserting that you, studying at the PhD level, and your own unnamed review from a health practitioner, are more trustworthy than the author of the example I provided. That's fine: disagreement is just making the point I made. It isn't settled science. It doesn't even really matter whether the source of disagreement is sugar lobby lies, Coca Cola or whatever. What I said is that there is disagreement which is why sugar addiction isn't mentioned. In relation to the quote: I was linking it to OP's described behaviour, but Fairburn also disagrees with the theory that 'people who binge are biologically vulnerable to certain foods (typically sugar and starches) and as a result become "addicted" to them. These foods are "toxic" to these people who, as a result, are unable to control their intake so their consumption progressively rises. Since this vulnerability is biologically based, they can never be cured of the problem (or "illness"): rather, they have to learn to accept it and adjust their lives accordingly.' 'Is the addiction model valid? As Terence Wilson of Rutgers University has stressed, nowadays the "concept of addiction has been debased by promiscuous and imprecise usage to describe virtually any form of repetitive behaviour. Some of us, we are told, are "sex addicts", others are "TV addicts" or "shopaholics". The result is that it is no longer clear what it means to have an addiction. When the word is used in this loose, all-embracing way, most of us could be said to be "addicted" to something or other.' Well done on finding a negative review of the first edition, I suppose. The second edition which I referred to was published in 2013, as well, so the reviewer may (or may not) have found some of the updates they want. Again, I was responding to the original poster who asked why people didn't seem to talk about sugar addiction a lot. I was not undermining the original poster, simply providing an answer. If that is a definition of concern trolling, it isn't a helpful one. Being able to accept that there are arguments and stances that you don't agree with is useful. Certainly interpreting people saying "I think this, but some other people think that" as concern trolling is a very defensive stance to take. Anyhow, I think the point that there isn't universal acceptance that sugar is addictive has been made by this discussion better than I could have made it alone. I am not interested in circular arguments, so I shall bow out of the thread.

The vast majority of people making the case that we should allow migrants in are not doing so in order to benefit people traffickers or because they want to see British culture destroyed. They are doing it because they see desperate fellow humans driven to abandon all they know and chase a dream, and they feel compassion. Compassion is a very worthwhile human trait. I do think it's likely that resource scarcity (including habitable land) is going to reach a point where this becomes an issue where things get horrific, but we are not there yet. And until we get there, it is incumbent upon us as a society that wants to think of itself as generally moral and hospitable (note: neither of those things necessarily mean accepting of the unqualified right of people to cross borders) to find the best solution for us and also for the people in this situation. I believe that Atkins and other high protein diets fell out of favour for long term use because they were believed to increase health risks (https://www.healthline.com/health/too-much-protein#recommended-daily-protein). A lot of the studies on red meat etc seem to be from US populations where the quality of red meat can be very low due to farming methods and antibiotics. A lot may depend on the quality of the protein you eat, and your genes. Also with the amount of weight training you're doing, you'll be using that protein. Personally I tried Atkins for a while and found it good for weight loss and I felt great, but I didn't do it long term and I also enjoyed vegetables too much to skip them. Maybe stick with it whilst you feel good, get bloods done if you can afford it, and dial down the protein if you dial down your resistance training.
